member.remarks:
Implementation Notes:
Hash sizes are 48 and 64 bytes (384 and 512 bits).
Block sizes are 104, and 72 bytes (832, 576 bits).
Use the property to determine block sizes at runtime.
The method wraps the and DoFinal methods./>
The method resets the internal state.

SHA3 Keccak Slides.

member.name: T:CEX.Common.KeyGenerator
member.summary:
A helper class for generating cryptographically strong keying material.
Generates an array or a populated KeyParams class, using a definable Digest(Prng()) dual stage generator. The first stage of the generator gets seed material from the Prng provider, the second hashes the seed and adds the result to the state array. A counter array can be prepended to the seed array, sized between 4 and 32 bytes. The counter is incremented and prepended to the seed value before each hash call. If the Counter size parameter is 0 in the constructor, or the default constructor is used, the counter is provided by the default random provider.

example.description: Create an array of pseudo random keying material:

item.description: SHA-2 Generates key material using a two stage Hmac_k(Prng()) process.
Blake, Keccak, and Skein also use a two stage generation method; Hash(Prng()).
Seed provider can be any of the generators.
Hash can be any of the digests.
Default Prng is CSPPrng, default digest is SHA512.
Resources are disposed of automatically.

member.name: T:CEX.Processing.Factory.KeyFactory
member.summary:
KeyFactory: Used to create or extract a CipherKey file.
The Constructor requires a pointer to a MemoryStream for reading or writing; using Create() objects are written to the stream, with Extract() objects are read from the stream.
The Create(CipherDescription, KeyParams) method requires a populated CipherDescription and KeyParams class.
The Create(CipherDescription, SeedGenerators, Digests) method will auto-generate keying material.
The Extract() method retrieves a populated cipher key (CipherKey), and key material (KeyParams), from the key stream.

item.description: In CFB mode, only decryption can be processed in parallel.
Parallel processing is enabled on decryption by passing a block size of ParallelBlockSize to the transform.
ParallelBlockSize must be divisible by ParallelMinimumSize.
Parallel block calculation ex. int blocklen = (data.size() / cipher.ParallelMinimumSize()) * 100
NIST SP800-38A.

member.name: T:CEX.Cipher.Symmetric.Block.SHX
member.summary:
SHX: A Serpent cipher extended with an HKDF powered Key Schedule.
SHX is a Serpent implementation that uses an HKDF generator to expand the user supplied key into a working key integer array.

item.description: HKDF Digest engine is definable through the SHX(uint, Digests) Constructor parameter: KeyEngine.
Key Schedule is powered by a Hash based Key Derivation Function using a definable Digest.
Minimum key size is (IKm + Salt) (N * Digest State Size) + (Digest Hash Size) in bytes.
Valid block size is 16 bytes wide.
Valid Rounds assignments are 32, 40, 48, 56, 64, 80, 96 and 128, default is 64.

remarks.para: It also takes a user defined number of rounds between 32 (the standard number of rounds), all the way up to 128 rounds in 8 round sets. A round count of 40 or 48 is more than sufficient, as theoretical attacks to date are only able to break up to 12 rounds; and would require an enormous amount of memory and processing power. The transform in SHX is identical to the Serpent implementation SPX, it process rounds by first moving the byte input array into 4 integers, then processing the rounds in a while loop. Each round consists of an XOR of each state word (Rn) with a key, an S-Box transformation of those words, and then a linear transformation. Each of the 8 S-Boxes are used in succession within a loop cycle. The final round XORs the last 4 keys with the state and shifts them back into the output byte array.

The key schedule in SHX powered by an HKDF bytes generator, using a Digest HMAC (Hash based Message Authentication Code) as its random engine. This is one of the strongest: methods available for generating pseudo-random keying material, and far superior in entropy dispersion to Rijndael, or even Serpents key schedule. HKDF uses up to three inputs; a nonce value called an information string, an Ikm (Input keying material), and a Salt value. The HMAC RFC 2104, recommends a key size equal to the digest output, in the case of SHA512, 64 bytes, anything larger gets passed through the hash function to get the required 512 bit key size. The Salt size is a minimum of the hash functions block size, with SHA-2 512 that is 128 bytes.

When using SHA-2 512, a minimum key size for SHX is 192 bytes, further blocks of salt can be added to the key so long as they align; ikm + (n * blocksize), ex. 192, 320, 448 bytes.. there is no upper maximum. This means that you can create keys as large as you like so long as it falls on these boundaries, this effectively eliminates brute force as a means of attack on the cipher, even in quantum terms.
The Digest that powers HKDF, can be any one of the Hash Digests implemented in the CEX library; Blake, Keccak, SHA-2, or Skein. The default Digest Engine is SHA-2 512.

The legal key sizes are determined by a combination of the (Hash Size + a Multiplier * the Digest State Size); klen = h + (n * s), this will vary between Digest implementations. Correct key sizes can be determined at runtime using the property.

The number of diffusion rounds processed within the ciphers rounds function can also be defined; adding rounds creates a more diffused cipher output, making the resulting cipher-text more difficult to cryptanalyze. SHX is capable of processing up to 128 rounds, that is four times the number of rounds used in a standard implementation of Serpent. Valid rounds assignments can be found in the static property.

member.name: T:CEX.Cipher.Symmetric.Block.RHX
member.summary:
RHX: A Rijndael Cipher extended with an (optional) HKDF powered Key Schedule.
RHX is a Rijndael implementation that uses a standard configuration on key sizes up to 64 bytes (512 bits). On keys larger than 64 bytes, an HKDF bytes generator is used to expand the user supplied key into a working key integer array.

remarks.para: The key schedule in RHX is the defining difference between this and a standard version of Rijndael. if the cipher key input is beyond the standard lengths used in Rijndael (128-512 bits), instead of using an inline function to expand the user supplied key into a larger working array, RHX uses a hash based pseudo-random generator to create the internal working key array. When using a non-standard key size, the number of diffusion rounds can be set by the user (through the class constructor). RHX can run between 10 and 38 rounds.

item.description: When using a standard cipher key length the rounds calculation is done automatically: 10, 12, 14, and 22, for key sizes 126, 192, 256, and 512 bits.
HKDF Digest engine is definable through the RHX(uint, uint, Digests) Constructor parameter: KeyEngine.
Key Schedule is powered by a Hash based Key Derivation Function using a user definable Digest.
Minimum key size is (IKm + Salt) (N * Digest State Size) + (Digest Hash Size) in bytes.
Valid block sizes are 16 and 32 byte wide.
Valid Rounds are 10 to 38, default is 22.

remarks.para: HKDF: is a key derivation function that uses a Digest HMAC (Hash based Message Authentication Code) as its random engine. This is one of the strongest methods available for generating pseudo-random keying material, and far superior in entropy dispersion to Rijndael, or even Serpents key schedule. HKDF uses up to three inputs; a nonce value called an information string, an Ikm (Input keying material), and a Salt value. The HMAC RFC 2104, recommends a key size equal to the digest output, in the case of SHA512, 64 bytes, anything larger gets passed through the hash function to get the required 512 bit key size. The Salt size is a minimum of the hash functions block size, with SHA-2 512 that is 128 bytes.

When using SHA-2 512, a minimum key size for RHX is 192 bytes, further blocks of salt can be added to the key so long as they align; ikm + (n * blocksize), ex. 192, 320, 448 bytes.. there is no upper maximum. This means that you can create keys as large as you like so long as it falls on these boundaries, this effectively eliminates brute force as a means of attack on the cipher, even in post-quantum terms.
The Digest that powers HKDF, can be any one of the Hash Digests implemented in the CEX library; Blake, Keccak, SHA-2 or Skein. The default Digest Engine is SHA-2 512.

The legal key sizes are determined by a combination of the (Hash Size + a Multiplier * the Digest State Size); klen = h + (n * s), this will vary between Digest implementations. Correct key sizes can be determined at runtime using the property.

The number of diffusion rounds processed within the ciphers rounds function can also be defined; adding rounds creates a more diffused cipher output, making the resulting cipher-text more difficult to cryptanalyze. RHX is capable of processing up to 38 rounds, that is twenty-four rounds more than the fourteen rounds used in an implementation of AES-256. Valid rounds assignments can be found in the static property.

member.name: T:CEX.Cipher.Symmetric.Block.THX
member.summary:
THX: A Twofish Cipher extended with an (optional) HKDF powered Key Schedule.
THX is a Twofish implementation that can use a standard configuration on key sizes up to 256 bits, an extended key size of 512 bits, or unlimited key sizes greater than 64 bytes. On larger than 64 bytes, an HKDF bytes generator is used to expand the working key integer array. In extended mode, the number of transformation rounds can be user assigned (through the constructor) to between 16 and 32 rounds.

item.description: HKDF Digest engine is definable through the Constructor parameter: KeyEngine.
Key Schedule is (optionally) powered by a Hash based Key Derivation Function using a definable Digest.
Minimum key size is (IKm + Salt) (N * Digest State Size) + (Digest Hash Size) in bytes.
Valid block size is 16 bytes wide.
Valid Rounds assignments are set at 16 in standard mode, and 32, 40, 48, 56, and 64 in extended mode.
Valid Rounds assignments are 16, 18, 20, 22, 24, 26, 28, 30 and 32, default is 16.

remarks.para: HKDF: is a key derivation function that uses a Digest HMAC (Hash based Message Authentication Code) as its random engine. This is one of the strongest methods available for generating pseudo-random keying material, and far superior in entropy dispersion to Rijndael, or even Serpents key schedule. HKDF uses up to three inputs; a nonce value called an information string, an Ikm (Input keying material), and a Salt value. The HMAC RFC 2104, recommends a key size equal to the digest output, in the case of SHA512, 64 bytes, anything larger gets passed through the hash function to get the required 512 bit key size. The Salt size is a minimum of the hash functions block size, with SHA-2 512 that is 128 bytes.

When using SHA-2 512, a minimum key size for RHX is 192 bytes, further blocks of salt can be added to the key so long as they align; ikm + (n * blocksize), ex. 192, 320, 448 bytes.. there is no upper maximum. This means that you can create keys as large as you like so long as it falls on these boundaries, this effectively eliminates brute force as a means of attack on the cipher, even in post-quantum terms.
The Digest that powers HKDF, can be any one of the Hash Digests implemented in the CEX library; Blake, Keccak, SHA-2 or Skein. The default Digest Engine is SHA-2 512.

The legal key sizes are determined by a combination of the (Hash Size + a Multiplier * the Digest State Size); klen = h + (n * s), this will vary between Digest implementations. Correct key sizes can be determined at runtime using the property.

The number of diffusion rounds processed within the ciphers rounds function can also be defined; adding rounds creates a more diffused cipher output, making the resulting cipher-text more difficult to cryptanalyze. RHX is capable of processing up to 38 rounds, that is twenty-four rounds more than the fourteen rounds used in an implementation of AES-256. Valid rounds assignments can be found in the static property.

item.description: NIST AES Fips 197.

HMAC RFC 2104.

Salt size should be multiple of Digest block size.

Nonce and Ikm are optional, (but recommended).
